awd_titl_txt: Rapid: Impact of Hurricane Florence on Drinking Water Safety in Eastern and Central North Carolina: Rapid Assessment and Recommendations for Recovery and Resilience
awd_abstract_narration:
Hurricanes and resulting flooding can negatively impact drinking water supplies and services. These impacts include everything from service disruptions to contamination by microbial and chemical pollutants. Hurricane Florence resulted in extensive flooding in areas of North Carolina with high densities of hog and poultry farms, resulting in the release of human and animal excreta and associated pathogens to the environment. These releases have the potential to contaminate nearby community drinking water systems and private wells, but the extent and duration of these impacts are not well understood. The objective of this project is to assess the extent of pathogen releases resulting from Hurricane Florence in areas of North Carolina with high densities of farms and septic systems. The broader goals of this research are to engage local residents in the monitoring water systems in impacted areas through a citizen science approach, and produce recommendations to identify and address vulnerabilities of water systems and animal agricultural operations to help improve infrastructure decision-making for extreme weather events.

 
Hurricanes and other extreme weather events can impair the safety and continuity of drinking water services, with associated adverse health outcomes. Hurricane Florence severely impacted North Carolina counties with high densities of hog and poultry farms, as well as of private wells and septic systems, resulting in the release of human and animal excreta (and associated pathogens) to the environment, with the potential to infiltrate and contaminate nearby community drinking water systems and private wells. Increased occurrence of drinking water contamination and disease outbreaks has been observed following previous hurricanes, but the extent, duration, and determinants of such contamination and outbreak events are not well understood. We propose to assess the extent and persistence of multiple pathogens of health concern in different types of water supplies in impacted areas. This work will elucidate impacts of extreme weather events on occurrence and persistence of bacteria focusing on pathogens and antibiotic resistant bacteria or (ARBs), viruses, and protozoa in water supply networks and private wells near combined animal feeding operations (CAFOs), septic and sewage systems, and other fecal waste sources. These results will be used to produce preliminary recommendations to address identified vulnerabilities, to improve water quality and associated health outcomes for populations in disaster-prone areas to improve infrastructure and decision-making in a variety of US settings vulnerable to extreme weather events. The broader impacts of this work will also include engaging local residents in monitoring water systems in impacted areas through a citizen science approach, informing community members of risks associated with impacted public and private water systems through communication of the results of this work, and contributing recommendations for enhancing the resilience of public and private water systems to community members, utilities, health departments and agribusinesses in impacted areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Extreme weather events threaten the safety and continuity of drinking water services, with rainfall and flooding linked to disruption and contamination of drinking water systems, which in turn can cause adverse health outcomes. The recent extreme weather events of Hurricane Florence severely impacted North Carolina counties with numerous potential sources of microbial contamination, including onsite sanitation (septic) systems as well as concentrated animal agricultural operations.

 

A study on the Impact of Hurricane Florence on Drinking Water Safety in Eastern and Central North Carolina: Rapid Assessment and Recommendations for Recovery and Resilience was conducted from December 2018 through November 2021. The project conducted rapid cross-sectional and longitudinal assessments of the impact of Hurricane Florence and other weather events on the microbial water quality of private wells and public water systems in heavily impacted areas with high densities of CAFOs and septic systems. This work was designed to better understand the conditions under which contamination occurs, the extent and duration of the impacts, and the roles played by livestock operations and human sewage and septic systems as potential sources of contamination.

 

This work built relationships with stakeholders, characterized water samples from 109 private wells in three counties, and quantified the occurrence and persistence of contamination by different microbial indicators (including fecal indicator bacteria, coliphages, and antimicrobial resistant [AMR] organisms) in private wells in these NC settings. We were able to characterize and evaluate the nature and extent of such microbial impairment and have published the results.

Key results include the finding that fecal indicator bacteria (FIB, used as an indicator of bacterial contamination) were detected in 21% of samples and were weakly correlated with male-specific coliphage (an indicator of microbial risk from viruses) occurrence. Of samples that contained bacteria, 12% of the organisms tested were cefotaxime-resistant (an indicator of antibiotic resistance). Coliphage (virus indicator) occurrence appeared to be higher during periods of greater rainfall, and these viral indicators were still present a year after the insult took place in wells known to have been impacted by Hurricane Florence. This is an important finding of the study. It implies that detection of bacterial indicators may be a reliable method for an immediate evaluation of human health effects after an event, but viral indicators may be better for long-term monitoring.

 

Our data support the continued need for surveillance in unregulated private wells where monitoring is not federally regulated and routinely conducted, particularly in settings prone to impacts from extreme weather events, and in proximity to sources of fecal contamination including septic systems and concentrated animal agriculture activities. Our work supports pairing FIB with coliphages and/or sanitary inspections and land use data to better understand the microbiological quality of groundwater and better identify private wells most vulnerable to contamination for preventive actions to enhance resilience during extreme weather events.

 

Results of work partially support by efforts through this project also suggest that low-cost point-of-use filters may have limited efficacy in removing microbial hazards from well water, particularly viruses, based on data for indicator coliphages (Mulhern et al., 2021).

 

Results suggest that primary prevention through well siting and construction, monitoring, and remediation where necessary, may be more effective than filters in ensuring water safety and resilience during extreme weather events; where point-of-use or point-of-entry water treatment is used, care should be taken to ensure that treatment is adequate to achieve substantive reduction in viruses and indicators suitable for achieving safety during extreme weather events.

 

The results of this work are presented in two research articles:

  • Stallard, M. A., Mulhern, R., Greenwood, E., Franklin, T., Engel, L. S., Fisher, M. B., ... & Sozzi, E. (2021). Occurrence of male-specific and somatic coliphages and relationship with rainfall in privately-owned wells from peri‑urban and rural households. Water research X, 12, 100102.
  • Mulhern, R., Stallard, M., Zanib, H., Stewart, J., Sozzi, E., & Gibson, J. M. (2021). Are carbon water filters safe for private wells? Evaluating the occurrence of microbial indicator organisms in private well water treated by point-of-use activated carbon block filters. International Journal of Hygiene and Environmental Health, 238, 113852.
